The best examples not yet mentioned that spring to mind are The Incredibles, it's sequel and Scott Pilgrim.

The Incredibles has amazing shot composition, framing and lighting. The sequel amped it up further, there are some iconic shots from the film that I'd love to have framed in a photo. Scott Pilgrim just completely understands what it is and the cinematography really nails the feel of the film.

If you’re looking for something interesting, Wes Anderson movies are incredibly unique in their cinematography. It’s not as bold or technically impressive as many things on your list, but it’s damn impressive how immersive his films are with such a distinct style. Isle of Dogs is my personal favorite, but The Grand Budapest Hotel and Fantastic Mr. Fox are great choices as well.
Drive

Maybe the best thing to do is to follow the work of the best cinematographers!

Try those ones :

- **Emmanuel Lubezki**. He started with very sophisticated/artifical photography (*Sleepy Hollow*, *Baudelaire Orphans*...), and then became specialist of more realist/natural light, even if still sophisticated (*Tree of Life*, *Children of men*, *The Revenant*...). A taste for fine contrasts, for short focal, and difficult-amazing shots.
- **Roger Deakins** (the one who did *Skyfall*). Very subtle photography, sometimes very simple (i watched *Doubt*, which is not a great films, just for the pleasure to see how he renders skins in the winter!). Here are some of his greatest work : almost all the Coen Brothers films (*The Man Who Wasn't There*, *No Country for Old Men*...), *The Assassination of Jesse James*, *The Village*, *Blade Runner 2049* (his more stylized work to this date in my opinion), *1917*...
- **Pixar cinematrographers**. Go watch those movies again looking at the inspirational choices of light, the textures, the realism of light on unatural characters and forms... The more classy cinematography is the one made for *The incredible* and *Ratatouille* ; the most realistic light on the shorts *The Blue Umbrella* and *Piper* ; the bright color games on *Wall-E* (on which Deakins worked) and *Up*... Just look threw their filmography, even if the first films are a little raw.
- **Harris Savides**. Incredibly inventive et diversified, passed away too early sadly. His best works are the crepuscular *Birth*, the weirdly precise and artificial image of *Zodiac*, the beautiful followings all in blur and different lights of *Elephant*...
- **Claire Mathon**. A young french cinematographer, but she has already made two masterpieces: the color-rich *Portrait of the Lady in fire*, and the dreamy-grey-fluorescent *Atlantique*.
- **Mario Bava**. The king of color. You can just watch the light of his own films (he was also a director), who are just made to serve such visions. Just type "Mario Bava lighting" on youtube to see what it looks like... My favorite is *The Whip and the Body*.
- **Mark Lee Ping-bing**. The cinematographer of Hou Hsia-Hsien. Light poetry, very subtle, barely noticeable, like if light was a sensual thing. You can try two twin films: *Millenium Mambo* (which is all dark, night, crepuscular, artificial lights), and *Café Lumière* (which is all day light, glare, white summer light). His work on *The Assassin* is also incredible.
- **Benoît Debie**, the man of neon light and hallucinations. You can try the Noé films (*Irreversible*, *Enter the Void*), *Spring Breakers*, and the films where Gosling gave him the car keys, in a way, it's like a cinematographer's playground : *Lost River*.

Other names you can try: **Gregg Toland** (*Citizen Kane*), **Agnès Godard** (*Golden Door*), **Raoul Coutard** for cinematography in all liberty (*À bout de souffle*), **Gordon Willis** aka "the Prince of Darkness" as people called him (*Klute*), the shadows of **James Wong Howe** (*Pursued*), the simplicity and softness of **Pierre Lhomme** (*Maurice*), **Conrad Hall** (*Road to Perdition*), the once overpraised **Darius Khondji** (*Alien 4*, *Seven*...), the overhyped **Janusz Kamiński** (all recent Spielberg films)...
If you like raw cinema you should watch [Hunger](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K9IiUbBV4zc)

Check out Black Mirror. It's a TV show (now on Netflix). Each episode tells its own hour(ish) long self contained story about various potential dark futures of technological advancement. Very similar in tone and style to Ex Machina, basically the Twilight Zone for the 21st Century. It's depressing as hell but one of the best sci-fi thrillers around right now.

If you don't mind anime: Death Note.
Try Mr Robot

Gangster Number One - Gangster kills and tortures his way thru 60s-00's London criminal underworld

Layer Cake - Nice(ish) gangster tries to survive in 2000s London underworld.

BBC's Sherlock - Updated/modernized retelling of the famous literary detective.

Payback - Good ole fashioned criminal revenge movie starring Mel Gibson

The Sopranos - American gangster soap-opera that changed the way the game is played.

Hannibal - The TV show! H Lector is the star! I didn't really like the first season so much, but it really hit its stride from the 2nd season on! Give it time!

Killing Eve - Entertaining and fun yarn about a bookworm tracking down an international assassin.

Barry - About a hitman who accidentally winds up in an acting class and contemplates a career change.

Dexter - About a serial killer that you like and root for (just watch seasons 1-4, skip later seasons)

Zero Effect - Little seen movie about the world's greatest detective, Darryl Zero - starring Bill Pullman!

The Last Seduction - THE BEST femme fatale, IMO. Also with Bill Pullman! 

The Usual Suspects - A classic!

Matchstick Men - One of N Cage's better, and a young Sam Rockwell!. About confidence tricksters.

Killing them Softly - By this Australian dude who makes hyper-artsy stuff- he did that, Jesse James western with Casey Affleck. Has B Pitt.

Collateral - Jamie Foxx is terrorized by Tom Cruise at his most predatory, most sharkish. Super stylish thriller!

Heat - Probably the best crime/character study/heist movie that will ever get made. Just a guess...

&#x200B;

Historical Bonus Points!

Le Samourai & Le Cercle Rouge by JP Melville - 60s/70s French director who oozes cool and style. I think he's credited with inventing "Heist" movies.

The Killing - Did you know Kubrick made a heist flick?

Sunset BLVD - I don't know if anyone qualifies as a sociopath, but folks are pretty mean to one another in this one. It's still a shocking story today, but at the time it was mind-blowing to have an unlikeable main protaganist. Also, super-ballsy opening that's still like, "Whoa!" 

Double Indemnity - I think they made a remake? See the black and white with Fred MacMurray and Ed G Robinson! Way ahead of its time.

&#x200B;
